name: df-prod
params: setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5, class c0, class c1
body: |- wceq(cprod(s0, c0, c1), cio(s1, wo(wrex(s2, cz, w3a(wss(c0, cfv(cuz, cv(s2))), wrex(s3, cfv(cuz, cv(s2)), wex(s4, wa(wne(cv(s4), nat0), wbr(cseq(cv(s3), cmul, cmpt(s0, cz, cif(c1, nat1, wcel(cv(s0), c0)))), cli, cv(s4))))), wbr(cseq(cv(s2), cmul, cmpt(s0, cz, cif(c1, nat1, wcel(cv(s0), c0)))), cli, cv(s1)))), wrex(s2, cn, wex(s5, wa(wf1o(cv(s5), co(nat1, cfz, cv(s2)), c0), wceq(cv(s1), cfv(cseq(nat1, cmul, cmpt(s3, cn, csb(s0, cfv(cv(s5), cv(s3)), c1))), cv(s2)))))))))
comment: Define the product of a series with an index set of integers ` A ` . This definition takes most of the aspects of ~ df-sum and adapts them for multiplication instead of addition. However, we insist that in the infinite case, there is a nonzero tail of the sequence. This ensures that the convergence criteria match those of infinite sums. (Contributed by Scott Fenton, 4-Dec-2017.)
